pros: It was a great environment to work with!
cons: There was nothing cons about the work environment

pros: Supportive environment with new equipment
cons: New programing and developing program for enrollment

pros: I love working with students and some of my colleagues are wonderful to work with too. Telecommuting two days a week is a huge perk. Benefits are good.
cons: Teaching faculty can be full of themselves and can be rude and high-minded. My work and expertise is frequently dismissed despite the fact that I have the same level of education as most of them. Positions have been cut so many professional staff and even directors spend their time at the front desk answering phones. Total lack of accountability for long-time employees who are not performing. Lots of dead weight. Many departments and coworkers can create roadblocks to doing good work. I spend too many hours navigating dysfunctional behavior.

review_title: Beware of only one permanent faculty per degree program practice.
pros: One month off at Christmas and summers off
cons: Job is advertised as "tenure-track", but is still 10-month terminal, non- permanent. The model is only for one permanent faculty member per degree program. Lots of extra non-teaching work (committee work, recruitment, accreditation etc.) is expected.

pros: It was nice working with the students and helping them complete assignments
cons: the pay is low, especially for the amount of work you have to do

pros: Consistent schedule for the semester
cons: Only 4 hours per week

review_title: Good People, poor management for my situation
pros: Good Vacation and health insurance
cons: Terrible Dental insurance coverage here

pros:
-Great people 
-Wonderful supervisor
-Remote work flexibility depending on department
cons:
-Working under the constraints of a grant
-Inability to advance in current position

review_title: Great Colleagues - College in Constant Upheaval
job_title: Faculty, Assistant Professor in Rochester, NY
pros: Colleagues are great, facilities are good, and most students are motivated. The community is livable.
cons: College is in constant upheaval because of the past president's reorganizations, staff reductions, and hiring of incompetent administrators. And that is before COVID19. College refuses to negotiate on rank and salary for faculty and makes "take it or leave it" offers. Faculty teach 10 - 3 credit classes per year and are required to spend 30 hours advising, hold 150 office hours, and because of downsizing, serve on numerous committees. In addition, they are being constantly asked to volunteer to do additional work for no pay (partly to cover for eliminated positions). There are no longer any professional development funds available and faculty benefits are not particularly generous. There is much unrest among faculty and staff and neither the existing management nor the trustees seem to care.

review_title: Great students but not so great pay.
pros: Great students especially those in the evening classes.
cons: Adjuncts are not paid well.

job_title: Bookstore Receiving Associate in Rochester, NY
pros: Flexible with time being a student even outside of MCC
cons: Constantly changing process of how the store operates by semester

review_title: Monroe Community College Association: Employer of Choice
pros:
Strong Leadership
Competitive Pay
Excellent Benefits
Engaged and Talented Staff
Meaningful Work
cons: Employees spend their entire careers working at MCCA which, at times, results in limited employment openings.

pros: The staffs and environment are really nice
cons: You have to deal with students which sometimes , it's frustrating

pros: great colleagues to work with
cons: no support from admin and staff

pros: People, Rewarding, Schedule, Positional Growth, Networking Opportunities, Vacation Time, Benefits
cons: How long the hiring process is.

pros: Great working atmosphere great benefits
cons: Lower pay than most places for the line of work

review_title: Good benefits but not a good place to work
job_title: Environmental Health and Safety in Rochester, NY
pros: They have great benefits and are unionized.
cons: They are stuck in the past. The mentality "if it ain't broke don't fix it" applies vs the understanding that just because something functions on a level doesn't mean it cannot be improved upon. There isn't a lot of push for growth. The college is VERY top heavy.

pros: great benefits good pay great students
cons: higher ups don't listen often

pros: Can't think of anything that impressed me, unfortunately. I worked here for a couple of years and was pleased to secure a full-time position elsewhere.
cons: There's a history of contractual negotiating issues and associated contention/turmoil, sweeping threats or worries about layoffs due to declining enrollment that has yet to recover, several long-term administrators have been mysteriously and involuntarily "retired" after over 25 years of dedicated service (leaving numerous offices empty and positions unfilled for a long time now), departments have been consolidated and positions have also been eliminated altogether as a massive restructuring has occurred and continues to happen, and one campus is uncomfortably under construction causing issue to faculty and students attempting to hold class. This is not a college that grows it's faculty either. Nepotism has been a serious issue, hiring some highly unqualified people just as an obvious favor, or hiring others from out of state, instead of hiring qualified internal talent. Also, adjunct employees do teach a significant amount of the classes at this college, but are treated quite poorly. They are not provided health insurance, and only compensated at a fraction of what full-time teaching faculty earn for teaching the exact same classes. Professional development is mostly offered when semesters are not in session, which is not always convenient for everyone. Too many classes are clustered together in just a couple of days rather than spreading them out throughout the semester. I was very happy to leave. This is not a pleasant place to work - very unstable. I cannot recommend.

pros: Super Chill place to work
cons: The work hrs are kind of odd

review_title: My experience has been wonderful - I enjoyed my department, loved working with my supervisors.
pros: I love the interaction between the Staff/Faculty/Professionals and Students.  Students are our number one priority here.  I also like the fact that there are two campuses so it is able to meet the needs for many and in a very broad span of area.  The Downtown campus is especially viable to the needs of the students from the City and the westside of Rochester.
cons: With the yearly lowering of funds from the State - MCC has been cutting back hard on it's departments/opportunities.  Departments are being disassembled should people leave, no matter what they're position is  - and then reassembled by combining them with other departments - that sometimes does not make sense, but we make it work.

pros: MCC offers decent salary for adjuncts. Benefits include lots of professional development opportunities, can take one college course for free each semester, and access to campus resources.
cons: No benefits, no guarantee that you will be assigned classes, or that your classes will fill.  Union limits how many hours adjuncts may work, so many adjunct at other colleges as well.  Assignments are often given late, so makes it hard to schedule other part time work.  Very little office space shared by many adjuncts.  Since many adjuncts apply for full time openings when available, not likely to be hired full time.

review_title: MCC is an awesome place to work
job_title: Senior Computer Specialist in Rochester, NY
pros: The people.  Everyone is very pleased to work here and that attitude is both pleasant and quite contagious.  From the first day I started work here I noticed that nearly everyone I encountered was very pleasant and really seemed to enjoy being here.  After many years that has not changed.  I've seen people come and go, and throughout it all the general attitude has been extremely positive as well as professional.
cons: Salaries are a bit low, typical of academia.  The benefits are outstanding.  Both vacation and personal time available are excellent.  Often times I am the envy of my friends (in higher paying jobs) becasue of the amount of time off that I typically have available.

review_title: Management ranges from good to awful. Leadership is not employee friendly.
pros: There are many departments that are helpful and run smoothly.
cons:
There are too many people in administrative positions that make poor decisions, don't trust heir employees and even manage to pass the buck when they make a bad decision onto those employes. HR is aware of the issue but seems unwilling to do anything about it.

They are a two year community college that does not help their employees further their educations, yet have been increasingly requiring degrees beyond two years. They also have a tendency to hire from outside the college, which shows their lack of faith in their employees, yet the continually end up higher people who are not qualified for those positions or less qualified than current employees.

review_title: MCC - a great place to work
job_title: Adjunct Associate Prof  in East Rochester, NY
pros: The people who work there are almost universally very nice and very competent. Many of the teachers and staff actually went to MCC as students.
cons: As with being an adjunct anywhere, being one at MCC means you are at the mercy of the department you work in and its scheduler - you have limited choices for classes/times/days of week etc.

pros: Many students are some of the finest people on the planet.  Many are hard-working and dedicated to improving their lives.
cons: The decline in enrollment and negative changes under the current administration have made the atmosphere more negative than it has historically been.

pros: Direct Supervisor was very accommodating, the work was not overly strenuous, coworkers are generally enjoyable
cons: Management meddled with work a lot, poor communication often lead to scheduling conflicts, lack of resources

pros: Free housing and utilities, tuition reimbursement, professional development funds, great benefits
cons: Overwork their employees. You are getting paid for 40 hours/week but you'll be working 50 hours. They do not have enough staff for the size of the campus. RDs are on-call for emergencies 25% of the time. You'll regularly work nights, weekends, and holidays. You will often be up until 5am dealing with resident problems, fights, parties, medical emergencies, and suicidal residents. You will not be properly trained to handle these incidents. Sexual harassment is not taken seriously.

review_title: Was once a great place to work... no longer
pros: Most of the pros are now gone.  Once was a flexible, nimble, caring institution.
cons: Severe and unnecessary changes so that the current president controls everything.  She's hired yes men and women to do what she wants.  This has led to a disastrous decline in enrollment.

pros:
Diverse student population. 
Experienced and dedicated faculty.
cons: Compensation and working conditions for adjuncts leaves a lot to be desired. This is a national issue, however.

cons: Mcc has taken on a more Business environment than a family environment as it was 35 years ago.
